statement.tex: %text Prove that the relation $R$ in the set $A=\{1,2,3,4,5\}$ given by $R=\{(a,b):|a-b|$ is even$\}$, is an equivalence relation. %

step.context: %text For a relation $R$ in set $A$ to be an equivalence relation it needs to exhibit reflexivity, symmetry and transitivity. What the following an example of? $(2,4)=|2-4|=2=(4,2)=|4-2|=2$ %
step.reason: \begin{align} \text{Reflexivity:} &(a,a)\in R\, \forall\, a\in A \\ \text{Symmetry:} &(a,b)\in R \implies (b,a)\in R \\ \text{Transitivity:} &(a,b)\in R, (b,c)\in R \implies (a,c)\in R \end{align} \\ %text More generally, since $(a,b)=(b,a)$ therefore $R$ is symmetric. %
%text $(a,a)=|a-a|=0$, which is{\bf even} therefore relation $R$ is reflexive. %

step.tex: %text If $|a-b|$ is even and $|b-c|$ is even then $|a-c|$ is also even, therefore $R$ is transitive. %
step.reason:
\begin{align} &|a-b|= 2k \quad\text{(say)} \\ &|b-c|= 2m \quad\text{(say)} \\ &|a-c|= |\pm 2k \pm 2m|=2|\pm k\pm m| \\ \implies &|a-c| \in\text{even} \end{align} \\ %text Therefore, $R$ is also transitive. Hence, since $R$ is reflexive, symmetric and transitive, it is an equivalence relation.
%
